00724 /* \ingroup rpmpgp
00725  * 5.6. Compressed Data Packet (Tag 8)
00726  *
00727  * The Compressed Data packet contains compressed data. Typically, this
00728  * packet is found as the contents of an encrypted packet, or following
00729  * a Signature or One-Pass Signature packet, and contains literal data
00730  * packets.
00731  *
00732  * The body of this packet consists of:
00733  *   - One octet that gives the algorithm used to compress the packet.
00734  *   - The remainder of the packet is compressed data.
00735  *
00736  * A Compressed Data Packet's body contains an block that compresses
00737  * some set of packets. See section "Packet Composition" for details on
00738  * how messages are formed.
00739  *
00740  * ZIP-compressed packets are compressed with raw RFC 1951 DEFLATE
00741  * blocks. Note that PGP V2.6 uses 13 bits of compression. If an
00742  * implementation uses more bits of compression, PGP V2.6 cannot
00743  * decompress it.
00744  *
00745  * ZLIB-compressed packets are compressed with RFC 1950 ZLIB-style
00746  * blocks.
00747  */
00748 typedef struct pgpPktCdata_s {
00749     uint8_t compressalgo;
00750     uint8_t data[1];
00751 } pgpPktCdata;
00752 
00753 /* \ingroup rpmpgp
00754  * 5.7. Symmetrically Encrypted Data Packet (Tag 9)
00755  *
00756  * The Symmetrically Encrypted Data packet contains data encrypted with
00757  * a symmetric-key algorithm. When it has been decrypted, it will
00758  * typically contain other packets (often literal data packets or
00759  * compressed data packets).
00760  *
00761  * The body of this packet consists of:
00762  *   - Encrypted data, the output of the selected symmetric-key cipher
00763  *     operating in PGP's variant of Cipher Feedback (CFB) mode.
00764  *
00765  * The symmetric cipher used may be specified in an Public-Key or
00766  * Symmetric-Key Encrypted Session Key packet that precedes the
00767  * Symmetrically Encrypted Data Packet.  In that case, the cipher
00768  * algorithm octet is prefixed to the session key before it is
00769  * encrypted.  If no packets of these types precede the encrypted data,
00770  * the IDEA algorithm is used with the session key calculated as the MD5
00771  * hash of the passphrase.
00772  *
00773  * The data is encrypted in CFB mode, with a CFB shift size equal to the
00774  * cipher's block size.  The Initial Vector (IV) is specified as all
00775  * zeros.  Instead of using an IV, OpenPGP prefixes a 10-octet string to
00776  * the data before it is encrypted.  The first eight octets are random,
00777  * and the 9th and 10th octets are copies of the 7th and 8th octets,
00778  * respectively. After encrypting the first 10 octets, the CFB state is
00779  * resynchronized if the cipher block size is 8 octets or less.  The
00780  * last 8 octets of ciphertext are passed through the cipher and the
00781  * block boundary is reset.
00782  *
00783  * The repetition of 16 bits in the 80 bits of random data prefixed to
00784  * the message allows the receiver to immediately check whether the
00785  * session key is incorrect.
00786  */
00787 typedef struct pgpPktEdata_s {
00788     uint8_t data[1];
00789 } pgpPktEdata;
00790 
00791 /* \ingroup rpmpgp
00792  * 5.8. Marker Packet (Obsolete Literal Packet) (Tag 10)
00793  *
00794  * An experimental version of PGP used this packet as the Literal
00795  * packet, but no released version of PGP generated Literal packets with
00796  * this tag. With PGP 5.x, this packet has been re-assigned and is
00797  * reserved for use as the Marker packet.
00798  *
00799  * The body of this packet consists of:
00800  *   - The three octets 0x50, 0x47, 0x50 (which spell "PGP" in UTF-8).
00801  *
00802  * Such a packet MUST be ignored when received.  It may be placed at the
00803  * beginning of a message that uses features not available in PGP 2.6.x
00804  * in order to cause that version to report that newer software is
00805  * necessary to process the message.
00806  */
00807 /* \ingroup rpmpgp
00808  * 5.9. Literal Data Packet (Tag 11)
00809  *
00810  * A Literal Data packet contains the body of a message; data that is
00811  * not to be further interpreted.
00812  *
00813  * The body of this packet consists of:
00814  *   - A one-octet field that describes how the data is formatted.
00815  *
00816  * If it is a 'b' (0x62), then the literal packet contains binary data.
00817  * If it is a 't' (0x74), then it contains text data, and thus may need
00818  * line ends converted to local form, or other text-mode changes.  RFC
00819  * 1991 also defined a value of 'l' as a 'local' mode for machine-local
00820  * conversions.  This use is now deprecated.
00821  *   - File name as a string (one-octet length, followed by file name),
00822  *     if the encrypted data should be saved as a file.
00823  *
00824  * If the special name "_CONSOLE" is used, the message is considered to
00825  * be "for your eyes only".  This advises that the message data is
00826  * unusually sensitive, and the receiving program should process it more
00827  * carefully, perhaps avoiding storing the received data to disk, for
00828  * example.
00829  *   - A four-octet number that indicates the modification date of the
00830  *     file, or the creation time of the packet, or a zero that
00831  *     indicates the present time.
00832  *   - The remainder of the packet is literal data.
00833  *
00834  * Text data is stored with <CR><LF> text endings (i.e. network-normal
00835  * line endings).  These should be converted to native line endings by
00836  * the receiving software.
00837  */
00838 typedef struct pgpPktLdata_s {
00839     uint8_t format;
00840     uint8_t filenamelen;
00841     uint8_t filename[1];
00842 } pgpPktLdata;
00843 
00844 /* \ingroup rpmpgp
00845  * 5.10. Trust Packet (Tag 12)
00846  *
00847  * The Trust packet is used only within keyrings and is not normally
00848  * exported.  Trust packets contain data that record the user's
00849  * specifications of which key holders are trustworthy introducers,
00850  * along with other information that implementing software uses for
00851  * trust information.
00852  *
00853  * Trust packets SHOULD NOT be emitted to output streams that are
00854  * transferred to other users, and they SHOULD be ignored on any input
00855  * other than local keyring files.
00856  */
00857 typedef struct pgpPktTrust_s {
00858     uint8_t flag;
00859 } pgpPktTrust;
00860 
00861 /* \ingroup rpmpgp
00862  * 5.11. User ID Packet (Tag 13)
00863  *
00864  * A User ID packet consists of data that is intended to represent the
00865  * name and email address of the key holder.  By convention, it includes
00866  * an RFC 822 mail name, but there are no restrictions on its content.
00867  * The packet length in the header specifies the length of the user id.
00868  * If it is text, it is encoded in UTF-8.
00869  *
00870  */
00871 typedef struct pgpPktUid_s {
00872     uint8_t userid[1];
00873 } pgpPktUid;
00874

00884     pgpPktEdata edata;          
00886     pgpPktLdata ldata;          
00887     pgpPktTrust tdata;          
00888     pgpPktUid uid;              
00889 };

00936 static inline
00937 unsigned int pgpGrab(const uint8_t *s, size_t nbytes)
00938 {
00939     size_t i = 0;
00940     size_t nb = (nbytes <= sizeof(i) ? nbytes : sizeof(i));
00941     while (nb--)
00942         i = (i << 8) | *s++;
00943     return i;
00944 }
00945 
00952 static inline
00953 size_t pgpLen(const uint8_t *s, size_t * lenp)
00954 {
00955     if (*s < 192) {
00956         (*lenp) = *s++;
00957         return 1;
00958     } else if (*s < 255) {
00959         (*lenp) = ((((unsigned)s[0]) - 192) << 8) + s[1] + 192;
00960         return 2;
00961     } else {
00962         (*lenp) = pgpGrab(s+1, (size_t) 4);
00963         return 5;
00964     }
00965 }
